stem: The nurse is caring for a patient receiving mechanical ventilation. Which of the following interventions are essential to prevent ventilator-associated events (VAE)? Select all that apply.

itemContext.sbar: 15:00 Report: Dr. Lee, this is Nurse Jones reporting on John Smith, 68-year-old male, admitted for pneumonia and ARDS. He's currently on mechanical ventilation, FiO2 60%, PEEP 10 cm H2O, tidal volume 450 mL, rate 16. Saturation is fluctuating between 90-92%. He's on continuous sedation with propofol and fentanyl. His last ABG at 14:00 showed pH 7.32, PaCO2 50, PaO2 65, HCO3 24. He has a new onset of purulent sputum. Temperature is 38.5°C. Chest X-ray shows worsening infiltrates. White blood cell count is elevated at 15,000. We are awaiting culture results. I'm concerned about possible VAP. Patient is on contact and droplet precautions. He is also hypotensive with a MAP of 60. I have started a bolus of NS per orders. I need orders for possible antibiotics and vasopressors.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 15,000/mm3, pH: 7.32, PaCO2: 50 mmHg, PaO2: 65 mmHg, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, Sputum Gram Stain: Gram-negative rods

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Propofol 20 mcg/kg/min IV, Fentanyl 50 mcg/hr IV, NS 500 mL bolus IV, scheduled Ceftriaxone 1g IV (pending order)

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: HR: 110 bpm, BP: 90/60 mmHg (MAP 60), RR: 16 (ventilator), Temp: 38.5°C, SpO2: 90-92%

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees reduces the risk of aspiration and VAP. Performing regular oral care with chlorhexidine helps reduce the bacterial load in the oral cavity. Suctioning secretions when needed prevents accumulation and reduces the risk of aspiration. Assessing endotracheal tube cuff pressure ensures adequate sealing to prevent leakage of secretions. Minimizing sedation helps reduce the duration of mechanical ventilation and the risk of complications.
rationale.incorrect: Using sterile water for oral care can increase the risk of bacterial growth. Routine instillation of normal saline into the endotracheal tube is not recommended and can dislodge secretions deeper into the lungs. Changing ventilator circuits daily is not necessary and can increase the risk of contamination. Administering prophylactic antibiotics can lead to antibiotic resistance.
clinicalPearls: VAP prevention bundles significantly reduce the incidence of VAP and improve patient outcomes.
Consistent implementation of evidence-based practices is crucial for VAP prevention.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting options that seem generally 'good' but are not specifically related to VAP prevention or are outdated practices.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on evidence-based interventions specifically aimed at reducing the risk of VAP, considering the patient's current condition and the SBAR information.

mnemonic.title: VAE Prevention
mnemonic.expansion: HOB (Head of Bed elevation), Oral Care (Chlorhexidine), Suction (PRN), Cuff Pressure (Monitor), Sedation (Minimize)

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees.
Use sterile water for oral care.
Perform regular oral care with chlorhexidine.
Routinely instill normal saline into the endotracheal tube.
Assess endotracheal tube cuff pressure regularly.
